review_title: Low-paying gig but benefits are good
job_title: Assistant Director of Annual Giving in New London, CT
pros: The benefits at Connecticut College were strong -- prior to the COVID-19 pandemic. 401 (b) retirement with a 10% employer contribution after vesting for two years; ample vacation & sick time, etc. My colleagues are, for the most part, wonderful to work with.
cons:
Conn severely underpays, compared to other NESCAC private colleges, universities and colleges in CT, and non-profits in the area. The amazing benefits package is something to consider, but it doesn't outweigh the fact Conn pays less than industry average for most jobs. It's almost impossible to get a raise once you've been hired unless you get a promotion, and that takes a significant amount of time. 
Since the COVID-19 pandemic, the majority of staff have been succeeding, surpassing goals, and working remotely. Effective August 2nd, 2021, all staff are expected to be back on-campus full-time, with very few exceptions. Many of my colleagues are now looking for other employment, that's more flexible, due to these policies. Our retirement benefits have not been fully reinstated, it's difficult to take time off without getting contacted by team members/directors, and departments are understaffed. Company morale has decreased dramatically given the latest employee updates from Human Resources.

review_title: Looks good on paper, but don't judge a college by its tuition.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New London, CT
pros:
Most of the staff "underlings" are wonderful to work with and friendly. The campus is well kept and there has been forward momentum for a few years now. There is more staff here than most other colleges of its size.

The benefits are fantastic! Summer hours, great med/dental/health, more vacation time than usual, but that doesn't mean you can always take advantage -- depends on your manager.

The New London area offers access to beaches, great restaurants, history, and relatively inexpensive housing. It's also less than an hour from three major cities, but far from other amenities you may be used to if coming from a larger city.
cons:
What the college makes up for in prestige, it lacks in endowment, forward-thinking, and management. The atmosphere is highly political, which has left the college at least 10 years behind its competitors, and there's little to no room for professional growth or risk taking.

The competitiveness between senior admins, and the lack of a senior VP to make them all "play nice," frequently trickles down to middle management, making for a less than favorable work environment. Should you be unlucky, don't rely on HR to be in your corner as they are #4 down the line of authority.

The New London area is also in a decline and lacks diverse activity and business.
